text:
- Good morning.
- Good morning.
- Thanks for joining us in the AWS Studio.
- Thanks for having me.

- Tell me a little bit about
your role at Vodafone Business.

- Sure, so maybe I'll start
with what Vodafone Business does

and then I can kind of show
where I fit within that.

So, Vodafone Business serves
three different segments

and we've just added a new
one, which is developers,

but we also serve large
corporates, multinationals.
We serve small and medium enterprises,
and we serve up to nine employees,
small and home office customers.

And we have two real missions
in terms of what we do.
For the larger corporates,
look at bringing to life the applications

that are going to change the
way businesses experience
the digital world.

And we do that by providing
the next generation

infrastructure layer which
sits at the intersection
of cloud, software defined networking, 5G.

And then on the SME
champion or the SME side,

what we try to do is be the
champion for SMEs across Europe.
So looking at how can we provide them
with the digital tools to transform,
so that they can compete,

just as if they were a
large corporate as well.
And then my role within that,

is I run a portfolio of
products that covers cloud,

edge computing, and
mobile private networks.

- Wonderful, well, of course,
today we're here to talk about
not just mobile edge computing or MEC,
but how you architect for that at scale.
How you're working with customers.
Does the developer ecosystem matter?
And if so, how? So much to impact today.
Let's start with, how do you see MEC?

How are you looking at the
convergence of network and cloud?

What, what's your strategy
for attacking that space?
- Yeah, so I am so excited to be in telco
at this particular moment in time,

because there is a massive
transformation happening.
As you start to launch things like 5G

and our standalone core and
software defined networking,
all of a sudden the networking layer

which used to be, you know,
properly dig a hole, plug it in,
long lead time to provision a service,

it's now all going to be available
on demand, as through APIs.

And therefore, like the
difference between say,
a computing layer and a networking layer,
is completely converging.

And what we're just doing is
providing another resource
to an application that is going to help it
optimize its performance on demand.

So seeing that all come together
is really, really exciting.
And I think one of the way that translates
into my portfolio strategy,

is I kind of think about
my portfolio as being,

how do you optimize the
way applications work
across the cloud to edge continuum,

whether it's a mobile
private network on campus

or our distributed edge or
you know, the core cloud,

that continuum and
taking advantage of that

and exposing that to customers,
both the compute resources

and the network resources so
that they can intelligently
optimize their applications across.

That's what gets me out
of bed in the morning.
- Me as well when you think of it.
That continuum that you mentioned,
that's exactly how we describe it here,
the edge continuum.

We're meeting customers
where they are today
with the infrastructure solution
that best meets their needs.
An AWS wavelength,

one such solution that brings
that compute and storage
to the edge of telco networks,
the likes of Vodafone distributed MEC,
is incredibly powerful.
Let's define our terms here though.

What do we mean when we say
Vodafone distributed MEC?
How does it work?
- Yeah, so Vodafone looked across
our entire footprint in Europe and said,
we believe that 35 milliseconds end to end
really matters for applications.
That's where your inner ear
starts to get really uncomfortable,
if there's more than 35 milliseconds

of latency in a mixed
reality or, you know,
high definition cloud gaming service.
So we said, okay, how do we make sure
that any end point can get to the cloud
in 35 milliseconds or less?

And so we identified the strategic
locations in our network.
We worked with AWS and have basically

packaged up access to AWS
cloud through wavelength

in these strategic locations
across our footprint.

So we've got two
wavelength sites in the UK,

three in Germany, and I'm
really excited to say,

we've just launched a pilot
zone in Spain as well.

- Congratulations.
- Thank you.

- Let's talk a little bit
about the enterprise experience
with interacting with this infrastructure.
They're going to ask all about,
what's my cloud journey going to look like
now that I'm joining forces,

not just with AWS but
with Vodafone as well.
Can you comment on that?

- Yeah, so one of the things
that's really important,
I think to both of us,

is that we help customers
figure that journey out.

So we've launched the
edge innovation program,

so that customers can sign
up and they get, you know,
support from AWS and support from Vodafone

to look at if you want to
deliver this experience
to an end user on a device,
where do you need to run your workloads
to deliver the optimal experience?
And that probably isn't going to be

a wholesale lift and
shift of your application
from AWS into wavelength.

We'll look at what workloads
need to go into wavelength,

how you move them, how
you adopt containers.

And then the thing that we
were talking a lot about,
is the network APIs that can help you
optimize that experience as well.

So we've launched an
edge discovery service,

so an application can
query the network and say,
where is the compute resource

that is going to deliver
the best experience for me?

And it'll direct you to
the right wavelength zone.
So yeah, I think you'll start to see
that network and cloud
all feeling like resources
that the application can call on demand.

- I think that's an
incredibly powerful experience

that developers are going
to have finally interacting
with the network as an asset.
One thing that I love saying is,
I think it's finally now the time

where the network is an asset
to application builders,

particularly with the advent
of high speed 5G networks.
Is that the same message
that you're communicating to customers?
- Yeah, absolutely, absolutely.

And we've just launched our
own developer marketplace
and engagement channel just for that,
to help developers discover and understand
how to use network resources.
And we've been talking a lot

about how to make that
really easy for developers

and how to make sure that
everything is consumable,

understandable, how do we
abstract as much of the dark art

of networking and understanding
that network for developers,
so it's super easy to use?
- So let's dive a little bit deeper
into a practical example.
I hear a rumor that there's going to be
some sort of guitar performance.

I'm a guitarist by trade,
I'm highly curious.

How does this network API
actually work in the wild?
- Yeah, so we have this fantastic company,
called Open Sesame,
who have an application called Sync Stage.
And in this particular demo,
we have gotten guitarists together,
together, virtually, one in the UK,
one in the US, and one in Canada.

And when they're ready
to start their session,

the application, the
Sync Stage application,

queries the network, okay,
this guy's in London,

this guy's in the states,
this guy's in Canada,

which MEC should they
attach themselves to?
So then they can spin up
their own instance of the application,

but it's interconnected,
the MECs are interconnected,
and then the Sync Stage application

provides the right buffer
that sort of latent, sorry,

that jitter predictability
for the application,
so that they can all be hearing each other
at exactly the right point.
So yeah, it's very exciting.
We'll have videos that we can push out
and you can see how it worked in practice,

five generations of music
from the fifties to today,
running on 5G.

- So this example of
integrating the network API
into one real tangible example
of reimagining the consumer experience
for enjoying and collaborating with music.

How does that align with
your broader strategy
to engage developers as a whole?

- I think our broader
strategy to engage developers

is to give them as much
support as possible
to come into into the 5G MEC,
to explore it, to try it, to test it,

to make sure that that
experience is optimized.
I would say we are open
to working with any kind of developer,
like a B2C developer, a B2B developer,

or even companies that might
be just building services

that make the abstraction
of the network in the cloud
easier for developers to consume.

- And I've got to imagine
that the partner ecosystem

plays an ever critical role in
this, just like Open Sesame.
- Yeah, absolutely.
We have our edge innovation program,

but we'll also be working
with the 5G Future Forum,
which is the group that facilitated
this cool demo of the guitarist.
We are also launching

an ecosystem acceleration
program through that.

So you can work actually
with multiple telcos at once,
trying to simplify those APIs,

and making sure that
those APIs are consistent,

regardless of what network
you're operating in
and indeed in the future,

also while you're roaming
and things like that.
So I'm super excited.

I think bringing more developers
to experiment into the MEC,
is going to help us build better services

across the entire network,
not just in the MEC,

but looking at how do we
make sure we can optimize
the entire estate of what Vodafone does
and expose it to developers,
so they can get the most richness
out of the network that they can.

- One of the things we talk
a lot about here at AWS
is the ability to go global in minutes.

And I think the interoperability
of the network APIs

that are being created
express precisely that,
that's what developers are asking for.
That's exactly what we need to deliver.
But if we zoom out for a second,
sure, you can build an application

for a global stage, just
like Open Sesame is doing,

but what makes Vodafone
distributed MEC unique?

- I think Vodafone is the
first to have launched MEC
across multiple countries.
And Vodafone is a, you know,
very strong player in Europe.
And Europe is,

they're not small, but they
are smaller geographically
in terms of countries, right?

So roaming and like passing
from one country to another
is much more of a reality for us.
So we are really interested in making sure

that you can get that
consistent quality of latency
anywhere that you go across Europe.
So we've been working with you
and the 5G FF and others

to look at how do we make
sure that we can have

that kind of quality
consistency across Europe?

And also even if you are in
say, Germany and you are,

you know, in Munich and
then you go up to Berlin,
how do we make sure that that workload
follows you to the right MEC?
And that really requires

a fantastic set of handshakes
between AWS and Vodafone
to say, here's where the end point is,
here's when they're crossing over,

here's how we make sure
that we orchestrate
the workloads to move across.
And all of those puzzles, I think,

have been a really unique
way of working with Vodafone.
- And I know I'm super excited

about this unique
architectural opportunity,

if I put on my solution
architecture hat here for a second.

Got multi edge,
multi-country, multi-region.
If I'm the developer, I'm like,

so what I'm deploying this
all sorts of different times?
Do I have to manage this?

We think about the value
proposition of AWS,
it's always about removing
the undifferentiated heavy lifting.

So I know we're doing some
work with HashiCorp leaders

and infrastructure as code
to really make life easier.
Anything you want to comment on that?

- Yeah, I mean, I think
any way that we can,
I was talking about handshakes, right?

Like I feel like it's our job
to build those handshakes,

so that it's completely
abstracted for the developer.

All they need to know is
that their application

is getting the right service
with the right parameters

of let's say, bandwidth
and latency and jitter.
They're getting that,

so that their application
performs the best.
AWS and Vodafone and other telcos
that are working on the same set of APIs,
we can take that pain away,
to make sure that that set of handshakes
just happens in the background
without them worrying about it.
- One of the areas I'm most excited about
is collaborating developer to developer,

Vodafone and AWS together
to make lives easier

for enterprises in managing
these applications at scale.
We're looking at together things,
like service mesh technologies,
we're looking at how you can use
networking constructs within AWS,
to really abstract away that complexity
and super excited to continue working
with your teams on those challenges.
But zoom out for a second,

what are some other things
you're excited about
for the developer ecosystem as a whole?
Whether it's exposing APIs,
creating a dedicated go-to-market motion,

how do you think about the
weeks and months to come
from that perspective?
- Well, I think,

what you'll start to see
is more and more APIs

in that roadmap being
published and coming out

and just driving adoption,
driving feedback,
making sure that these are easy to use
and consume for the end customers.
Within Vodafone,

we are continuing to drive
our edge innovation program.
So we've got some really cool companies
that we're working with.

We're starting a pilot with
Imperium Drive, which is remote.
They do, sort of remote driving, yeah?
So if you rent a car,

sometimes it can be a
complete pain, right?
To like go to the rental car.
How do you get to the rental car?

Do you have to take a
taxi to the rental car,

because obviously if you
had a car to get there,
you wouldn't be renting the car.

So they actually are
developing a technology

that will remotely drive
that rental car to you.

So super, super cool pilot
that will be running in the UK.
Very excited about that.

And you just introduced
us to a fantastic company,

Confluent, and they are
looking at bringing this,

the processing and the
machine learning of data

closer to the device and
the endpoints that need it.

So all sorts of things
which honestly are good

for my edge portfolio, but also
for mobile private networks.

Things like predictive
maintenance, digital twins.

How do we make sure that all
of those services are available

at the edge to our customers
in a very simple way?
- So let's zoom out for a second.

One of our big themes this
year is all about next level.
Talk to me about the next level

of distributed MEC in
partnership with AWS.
- Oh wow.
So I think the next level of AWS MEC,

is you'll start to see
more and more solutions

going from pilot into
industrialized scale.

So looking at how we can drive
and support our own customers
like Imperium Drive, for example,
to go from piloting on the MEC,

to actually being able to
scale and productionize.

- Well, it's a fascinating
discussion today.

Thanks so much for
joining us in the studio.
- Thank you.
- Can't wait to continue working together.
- Excellent. Thank you.
